{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3244368,"name":"joel truher","username":"truher","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/truher/{size}/172222_2.png","created_at":"2023-10-24T02:40:22.873Z","cooked":"

Hi everybody (especially @Oblarg),

We’re planning to overhaul our logging this fall, with the goal of supporting USB logging through DataLogManager, and live logging through Glass, for all the quantities we need to see. There are no other goals – we don’t use Shuffleboard or SmartDashboard or whatever, and for us NT is just one-way, write-only.

In the past, we’ve used Sendables, and we’ve started to just use NetworkTables directly, but it’s quite verbose. I’ve been looking at the Oblog annotations, and I’m curious if that would give us what we need? Does Oblog work with DataLogManager?

Thanks!

AdvantageKit does a lot more than just logging. If you have no other goals than just logging data, the SmartDashboard interfaces are pretty straightforward (and everything put to NT gets logged). Unfortunately, I’m not sure Oblog is still being maintained; @Oblarg?

re smartdashboard, yeah, my annoyance with it is that I’d like to minimize magic. you put a key and a value in one end, you get them out the other. I like the NT4 direct route for that reason, it’s just so wordy.

We’ve been using DataLogManager with joystick logging enabled by adding this code to my robot init:

import edu.wpi.first.wpilibj.DataLogManager;
import edu.wpi.first.wpilibj.DriverStation;

// Starts recording to data log
DataLogManager.start();

// Record both DS control and joystick data
DriverStation.startDataLog(DataLogManager.getLog());

// (alternatively) Record only DS control data
DriverStation.startDataLog(DataLogManager.getLog(), false);

anything you send to smartdashboard will be logged with a timestamp then we use advantagescope to view our logs

FIRST Robotics Competition Documentation

On-Robot Telemetry Recording Into Data Logs

By default, no telemetry data is recorded (saved) on the robot. The DataLogManager class provides a convenient wrapper around the lower-level DataLog class for on-robot recording of telemetry data ...

","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":20,"updated_at":"2023-10-24T04:08:17.060Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":6,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":165,"readers_count":164,"score":43.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":442962,"topic_slug":"logging-with-oblog-nt4-datalogmanager","display_username":"Joe Ross","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://docs.wpilib.org/en/stable/docs/software/telemetry/datalog.html#standard-data-logging-using-datalogmanager","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"On-Robot Telemetry Recording Into Data Logs — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation","clicks":9}],"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":7841,"username":"Tom_Line","name":"Tom Line","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/tom_line/{size}/236809_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":true,"admin":false,"staff":true,"user_id":65,"hidden":false,"trust_level":4,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/logging-with-oblog-nt4-datalogmanager/442962/7","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3244429,"name":"Peter Johnson","username":"Peter_Johnson","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/peter_johnson/{size}/10417_2.png","created_at":"2023-10-24T06:46:24.674Z","cooked":"

Yeah the NT API is verbose mainly because of all the functionality it needs to expose. There’s a clear tension between minimizing magic and being verbose, it sounds like you want something in between the two. There’s a proposal for an higher-level Telemetry API that would supersede SmartDashboard that might match what you’re looking for, but the first attempt at an implementation stalled out because it seemed like it essentially evolved into a reimplementation of what already exists in Sendable.

Oblog does not work with DataLogManager. If you’re looking at 2024, I’m developing a “spiritual successor” to Oblog that has integration with DataLog and NT4.

For “Yet Another NT4 Based Logging Solution”, python edition:

github.com

RobotCasserole1736/firstRoboPy/blob/master/utils/signalLogging.py

import os
import wpilib
import ntcore as nt
import wpiutil._wpiutil.log as wpilog # pylint: disable=import-error,no-name-in-module

from utils.faults import Fault 


BASE_TABLE = "SmartDashboard"

# Wrangler for coordinating the set of all signals
class _SignalWrangler:

    # Starts up logging to file, along with network tables infrastructure
    # Picks approprate logging directory based on our current target
    def __init__(self):
        # Default to publishing things under Shuffleboard, which makes things more avaialble
        self.table = nt.NetworkTableInstance.getDefault().getTable(BASE_TABLE)
        self.publishedSigDict = {}
        self.sigUnitsDict = {}
This file has been truncated. show original

Critically, we wanted to wrapper NT4 and logging such that:

  1. A trivial interface for indicating what needed to be logged - restricting to scalar doubles and Booleans was acceptable.
  2. Automatically dump “thing to be logged” into NT4 where every tool for debugging could see it, plus put it to disk so we could extract log files after the match
  3. Do not naively log everything in NT, since we’ve been known to abuse it in the past
  4. Samples from the same loop should have aligned timestamps

While we’d rather have java annotations, we settled for

log("name of thing", val_of_thing)

ok, sounds like we should make our own thing, which is fine.

while i have the log-interested folk’s attention, is there some simple trick to get the Driver Station Log fields (e.g. battery voltage, CAN utilization, rio CPU, etc) into the DataLogManager USB output?

Battery Voltage and CAN Utilization are exposed in the RobotController class along with potentially other useful things. See getBatteryVoltage() and getCANStatus()

Oblog works over NT, and so works with WPILib data logs implicitly if you (as described above) turn on logging of NT values. It is not as performant as calling the DataLogManager functions directly, but it shouldn’t matter unless you’re logging a lot of things, or using some of the more deeply-reflective fanciness like the methodName feature.

I’d very much like to sunset Oblog in favor of a modern tool that integrates directly with the more-performant WPILog features, but I don’t have time to rewrite the tool from scratch and it doesn’t make sense to do absent some of the other telemetry reworks. Sendable is ancient and troublesome.

","post_number":16,"post_type":1,"posts_count":20,"updated_at":"2023-10-24T16:02:55.601Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":15,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":99,"readers_count":98,"score":34.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":442962,"topic_slug":"logging-with-oblog-nt4-datalogmanager","display_username":"joel truher","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":12381,"username":"Oblarg","name":"Eli Barnett","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/oblarg/{size}/161674_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":53190,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/logging-with-oblog-nt4-datalogmanager/442962/16","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3244815,"name":"joel truher","username":"truher","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/truher/{size}/172222_2.png","created_at":"2023-10-24T21:33:16.736Z","cooked":"

This is what we came up with, in case anyone is curious.

public class Telemetry {
    private static final Telemetry instance = new Telemetry();
    private final NetworkTableInstance inst;
    private final Map<String, Publisher> pubs;

    /** Uses the default network table instance. */
    public Telemetry() {
        inst = NetworkTableInstance.getDefault();
        pubs = new HashMap<>();
        DataLogManager.start();
    }

    public static Telemetry get() {
        return instance;
    }

    public void log(String key, boolean val) {
        pub(key, k -> inst.getBooleanTopic(k).publish(), BooleanPublisher.class).set(val);
    }

    public void log(String key, double val) {
        pub(key, k -> inst.getDoubleTopic(k).publish(), DoublePublisher.class).set(val);
    }

    public void log(String key, long val) {
        pub(key, k -> inst.getIntegerTopic(k).publish(), IntegerPublisher.class).set(val);
    }

    public void log(String key, String val) {
        pub(key, k -> inst.getStringTopic(k).publish(), StringPublisher.class).set(val);
    }

    public void log(String key, String[] val) {
        pub(key, k -> inst.getStringArrayTopic(k).publish(), StringArrayPublisher.class).set(val);
    }

    private <T extends Publisher> T pub(String key, Function<String, Publisher> fn, Class<T> pubClass) {
        Publisher publisher = pubs.computeIfAbsent(valid(key), fn);
        if (!pubClass.isInstance(publisher))
            throw new IllegalArgumentException("value type clash");
        return pubClass.cast(publisher);
    }

    private String valid(String key) {
        if (key.length() == 0)
            throw new IllegalArgumentException("empty key");
        if (key.charAt(0) != '/')
            throw new IllegalArgumentException("no leading slash");
        return key;
    }

    /** For testing. */
    Telemetry(NetworkTableInstance inst, Map<String, Publisher> pubs) {
        this.inst = inst;
        this.pubs = pubs;
    }
}

Nice, I like the external API shape. My only concern with that code is that the lambda in the log() functions will probably create a new object on every call. Potentially escape analysis will catch it and make it so it doesn’t hit the full GC, but I’m not sure if the JVM is that smart. Just something to be aware of if you make lots of log() calls.

The lambdas functions are small and simple enough that the JIT will inline them to direct method calls. It’ll take a few thousand invocations until the JVM determines that it’s an optimization target, though, so storing the functions in constants would avoid any object allocations until the JIT kicks in
